title: August 2012 Paper 2 - Licensure Exam
description: NCK Community Health Nurse (Basic) Licensure Examination Paper Two from August 2012. Covers MCQs, Short Answer, and Essay questions converted for interactive practice.

questions.question: The trophoblastic layer responsible for nourishing the growing organism during embedment process is:-
questions.explanation: The syncytiotrophoblast invades the endometrial wall and erodes maternal vessels to establish uteroplacental circulation.
questions.hint: The outer layer that 'sinks' into the uterine wall.

questions.question: Client Mi’s weight is 50 kgs at 20 weeks gestation. At 36 weeks she will weigh approximately:-
questions.explanation: Weight gain is approx 0.5kg/week in the second half. 16 weeks (36-20) x 0.5kg = 8kg gain. 50 + 8 = 58kg.
questions.hint: Gain is roughly 0.5kg per week.

questions.question: Mrs Ra, para 0+0 gravida 1 visits antenatal clinic with complaints of increased vaginal discharge. The specific intervention would include:-

options.text: Advice her to bring her partner for investigations, perform urinalysis.
Exclude possibility of infection, advice on hygiene.
Advice her to start douching, commence antifungal treatment.
Advice her to avoid tight inner wears, commence antibacterial therapy.

questions.explanation: Increased discharge is physiological (leukorrhea), but infection must be ruled out first. Blind treatment is inappropriate without diagnosis.
questions.hint: Is it normal or infection? Check first.

questions.question: The immediate action taken when a mother develops respiratory distress after administration of magnesium sulphate is:-

options.text: Give oxygen 4 litres/min, prop up the patient.
Summon for help, administer 10 mls of 10% calcium gluconate i.v. slowly.
Prop up the patient, summon for help.

questions.explanation: Calcium Gluconate is the specific antidote for Magnesium Sulphate toxicity (indicated by respiratory depression).
questions.hint: What is the antidote for Mag Sulph?

questions.question: The daily carbohydrate requirements for a Type 2 diabetes mellitus mother should be increased after delivery by:-
questions.explanation: Carbohydrates are increased by 30-50g to support lactation and prevent hypoglycemia.
questions.hint: Breastfeeding burns sugar.

questions.question: Appropriate interventions to minimize mother to child transmission of HIV during vaginal delivery include:-

options.text: Avoid perineal tears, wipe the baby immediately.
Avoid artificial rupture of membranes, rule out urinary tract infection.
Shorten duration of ruptured membranes (<4hrs), use chlorhexidine for cleaning.
Minimize number of vaginal examinations, rule out urinary tract infection.

questions.explanation: Prolonged rupture of membranes increases transmission risk. Cleaning the canal reduces viral load.
questions.hint: Keep membranes intact as long as possible and clean the canal.

questions.question: The importance of assessing the state of the cervix during labour is:-

options.text: To determine adequacy of the pelvis.
For accurate measurement of the cervix.
To determine if the woman meets criteria for implementation of partogram.

questions.explanation: The partogram starts in the Active Phase, which is defined by cervical dilatation (usually >=4cm).
questions.hint: When do you start the Partograph?

questions.question: On diagnosis of fetal distress, the fluid of choice to administer is:-

options.text: 500 mls of 10% dextrose for one hour.
1 litre of normal saline for 30 minutes.

questions.explanation: Normal Saline (crystalloid) improves perfusion without causing fetal hyperglycemia/acidosis like Dextrose.
questions.hint: Avoid sugar; use salt water to boost volume.

questions.question: Following administration of epidural anaesthesia during labour, blood pressure should be recorded every:-

options.text: 5 minutes for the initial 20 minutes, then at 15 minutes interval.
10 minutes for the first 2 hours, then half hourly.
15 minutes until the anaesthesia wears off.
10 minutes until the blood pressure reading is satisfactory.

questions.explanation: Hypotension is a rapid and common side effect; frequent (5 min) monitoring is critical initially.
questions.hint: Epidurals cause quick drops in BP.

questions.question: Mrs. Wi (previous C/S) at 36 weeks complains of intermittent right abdominal pain. Probable diagnosis is:-
questions.explanation: Scar pain in a previous CS mother is a warning sign of dehiscence/rupture.
questions.hint: The scar is under stress.

questions.question: Indicate True or False: i) Mother pushes immediately after 1st twin delivery. ii) Uterotonics are given after 2nd twin delivery.
questions.explanation: i) False: Confirm presentation/lie first. ii) True: Uterotonics after the *last* baby to prevent entrapment.
questions.hint: Don't push blindly; don't close the door (uterus) until everyone is out.

questions.question: Physical examination on a newborn on day 3 of life includes:-

options.text: Temperature, respiration, skin turgor and jaundice.
Breast engorgement, weight gain, range of movement.
Pus swab for culture, feeding pattern, wake and sleep pattern.
Ecchymatic mark, colour and odour of stool, weight gain.

questions.explanation: Day 3 checks: Jaundice (peak), Dehydration (turgor), and Infection (Temp/Resp). Weight usually drops, not gains.
questions.hint: Check for yellow skin and dry skin.

questions.question: Calculate Apgar: HR 110 (2), Gasping (1), Blue extremities (1), Some flexion (1), Minimal grimace (1).
questions.hint: Sum the components.

questions.question: Feed amount for 1600g baby on day 2 (approx 80ml/kg/day, 3 hourly):-
questions.explanation: 1.6kg * 80ml = 128ml/day. 128 / 8 feeds = 16ml per feed.
questions.hint: Weight x 80 divided by 8.

questions.question: Match the condition with its description:

pairs.right: Caused by fragile red blood cells
Maintains integrity of red blood cells (Defect causes loss)

questions.explanation: Spherocytosis = fragile RBCs. G6PD = enzyme defect affecting RBC integrity.
questions.hint: Sphere = shape (fragile). Enzyme = integrity.

questions.question: Common complications of a light for dates (SGA) baby include:-

options.text: Polycythaemia, congenital abnormalities, fetal alcohol syndrome.
Twin to twin transfusion, asphyxia, poor temperature control.
Polycythemia, meconium aspiration, twin to twin transfusion.

questions.explanation: SGA babies suffer from Hypoglycemia, Meconium Aspiration, and Infection risk.
questions.hint: Starved, stressed, and prone to infection.

questions.question: Immediate intervention for urine retention after delivery:-

options.text: Running tap water, sitting in a bath tub.
Applying warm compresses on perineum, catheterization.
Sitz bath, applying warm compresses on perineum.

questions.explanation: Try non-invasive sensory stimulation (running water/bath) first.
questions.hint: Try the simplest trick before using a catheter.

questions.question: Role of midwife in relieving after-pains:
questions.explanation: Empty bladder reduces pain. Analgesics treat it.
questions.hint: A full bladder makes the pain worse.

questions.question: Still births and deaths in the first week of life are classified as:-
questions.explanation: Perinatal = Stillbirths + Early Neonatal Deaths (0-7 days).
questions.hint: Peri means 'around' birth.

questions.question: Contraception for breastfeeding mother at 6 weeks postpartum:
questions.explanation: Microlut (POP) and IUCD are safe. Logynon/Microgynon (COCs) suppress milk.
questions.hint: No Estrogen.

questions.question: Match the labels for the female external genitalia:
questions.explanation: Standard anatomical definitions.
questions.hint: Identify the key structures from top to bottom.

questions.question: What are probable signs of pregnancy? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Probable signs are strong indicators (Signs) but not proof (Positive). FHS is a Positive sign.
questions.hint: Signs the examiner sees, but could technically be something else (like a tumor).

questions.question: What interventions are recommended for a Rhesus Negative mother? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Administer Anti-D within 72 hours of birth (if baby Rh+)

questions.explanation: Monitor antibodies, give Prophylaxis (Anti-D), treat events, and ensure hospital delivery.
questions.hint: Prevent sensitization using Anti-D.

questions.question: What are the Pillars of Safe Motherhood? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: FP, ANC, Safe Delivery, EOC, and Postnatal Care are the classic pillars.
questions.hint: The steps of the reproductive journey.

questions.question: Causes of Acute Uterine Inversion include: (Select all that apply)

options.text: Cord traction on a relaxed uterus

questions.explanation: Pulling when relaxed, pushing from top, or anatomical shortness causes the uterus to turn inside out. CCT during contraction is the *correct* technique.
questions.hint: Pulling or pushing when the muscle is floppy.

questions.question: Non-pharmacological pain relief methods in labour: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Physical and psychological methods without drugs.
questions.hint: Natural methods.

questions.question: Key interventions for an uneventful puerperium: (Select all that apply)

options.text: Keep patient in bed for 7 days

questions.explanation: Monitoring, Breastfeeding support, and Mobilization (not bed rest) are key.
questions.hint: Active management, not passive bed rest.

questions.question: Why use Progesterone Only Pills (POPs) for these clients?

pairs.right: Provides immediate protection as fertility returns quickly

questions.explanation: POPs protect milk supply. Post-abortion fertility returns within 2 weeks, requiring immediate coverage.
questions.hint: Milk and Immediate Fertility.

questions.question: Define Post Partum Haemorrhage (PPH).
questions.explanation: Blood loss >500ml (Vaginal) or >1000ml (CS) affecting maternal condition.
questions.hint: Think about the volume limit.

questions.question: Match the type of Lochia with its timing:
questions.explanation: Rubra (Red) -> Serosa (Pink) -> Alba (White).
questions.hint: Red, Pink, White sequence.

questions.question: Sequence of management for Secondary PPH (Infection/Retained tissue):
questions.explanation: Stabilize -> Contract uterus -> Treat Infection -> Remove cause (Tissue).
questions.hint: Stop bleeding, treat infection, remove retained bits.

questions.question: Match the circulatory change at birth with the structure:

pairs.right: Close due to clamping/cessation of flow
Closes as Left Atrial pressure exceeds Right
Constricts due to increased Oxygen levels

questions.explanation: Clamping stops flow. Pressure changes close the Foramen. Oxygen closes the Ductus Arteriosus.
questions.hint: Pressure closes the heart hole; Oxygen closes the lung bypass.

questions.question: Signs of a Term Baby's Neuromuscular Maturity: (Select all that apply)

options.text: Scarf sign: Elbow crosses midline easily

questions.explanation: Term babies are flexed and have strong tone/resistance. Preterms are floppy (Scarf sign crosses midline).
questions.hint: Term babies are tight and flexed; preterms are loose.

questions.question: Genital abnormalities in a male infant: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Common male issues: Testes location, urethral opening, fluid/hernia. Pseudo-menstruation is female.
questions.hint: Specific to male anatomy.
